presentation.title: Flood regulation
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from flood regulation by ecosystems
presentation.description: Values resulting from flood regulation by ecosystems, including precipitation, ecosystems capable of providing infiltration or detention of flood waters, and housing, infrastructure, or farmland at risk of flooding. Flow models are used to connect beneficiaries to potential sources of flood water and quantify the action of natural "sinks" that slow, detain, or infiltrate flood water.

page.name: Farmland at risk from flooding
page.title: Farmland at risk from flooding
page.description: This model considers floodplain farmland as a potential beneficiary of flood regulation. Depending on their magnitude and timing, floods can have devastating effects on crops. These models map flows from flood sources (precipitation), sinks (areas whose topography, vegetation, and soils promote detention and infiltration of flood water), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater. To map farms at risk of flooding, we simply intersect farmland with floodplain extents data for either the 100 or 500-year floodplain.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Public assets at risk from flooding
page.title: Public assets at risk from flooding
page.description: This model considers protection of public infrastructure as a potential beneficiary of flood regulation. Public infrastructure (e.g., transportation, energy, or water infrastructure) can be damaged by floodwater or the use of such infrastructure can be impaired by inudation (e.g., roads being impassable due to flooding). These models map flows from flood sources (precipitation), sinks (areas whose topography, vegetation, and soils promote detention and infiltration of flood water), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater. To map public infrastructure at risk of flooding, we simply intersect roads, railways, or other infrastructure with data delimiting the 100 or 500-year floodplain.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Residents at risk from flooding
page.title: Residents at risk from flooding
page.description: This model considers protection of human life and housing as a potential beneficiary of flood regulation. For people living in flood zones, floodwater can destroy housing and personal property and pose a risk to human lives. These models map flows from flood sources (precipitation), sinks (areas whose topography, vegetation, and soils promote detention and infiltration of flood water), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of floodwater. To map housing at risk of flooding, we simply housing data (where available) or NLCD developed land with data delimiting the 100 or 500-year floodplain.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Deforestation
page.title: Risk of deforestation
page.description:
Areas at greater risk of deforestation is are likely to lead to greater stored carbon release.

Role in models

The likelihood of deforestation and fire, combined with the quantity of stored carbon in an ecosystem, can predict the amount of stored carbon that is released during deforestation or fire. Deforestation acts as a particularly strong influence in the model in tropical nations with higher deforestation rates and weaker land tenure and enforcement of legal limits on forest clearing.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

GLCF (University of Maryland).
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.name: Successional Stage
page.title: Successional Stage
page.description: Forest successional stage is an important determinant of hydrologic balance, surface flow disruption, and sediment trapping capacity.

page.name: Elevation
page.title: Elevation
page.description: Altitude is a type of length whose use is specific to geophysical applications. By making it the observable in, e.g., an altitude raster layer, we know how to properly aggregate and distribute altitudinal data.

page.name: Gray Infrastructure Storage
page.title: Gray Infrastructure Storage
page.description: The sum of storage of floodwater by dams, detention basins, or other types of engineered infrastructure.

page.name: Green Infrastructure Storage
page.title: Green Infrastructure Storage
page.description: The sum of storage of floodwater in soils, vegetation, and floodplains.

page.name: Percent Vegetation Cover
page.title: Percent Vegetation Cover
page.description: Percent vegetative cover. IVMP makes notes of areas with >70% cover vs. <70% cover. Ask Paula if this is a useful threshold. Note that different vegetation types also have different rooting depths, root densities, and transpiration rates, affecting their ability to aid in infiltration of water and/or slowing of wind and wave energy.

page.name: Detention Basin Storage
page.title: Detention Basin Storage
page.description: Storage of flood waters in detention basins.

page.name: Annual Maximum Temperature
page.title: Annual Maximum Temperature
page.description: No description given

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potentially damaging flood flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow route of floodwater across the landscape in the absence of sinks. Therefore it computes the maximum damage that would happen if natural features did not intercept it, and provides a baseline that allows estimation of the actual value of those features.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Potentially damaging runoff
page.title: Source of potentially damaging runoff
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity actually has the ability to reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows us to identify which particular portion of the total source quantity is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use values, the structure of the landscape and the flow paths of the carrier, producing this *possible source map*. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows runoff capable of harming people or damaging property when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potential flood damage
page.description: This map shows people and property receiving damage when accounting for sources of floodwater and its flow path but not accounting for the action of sinks that reduce potential damage from floodwater.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual flood
page.title: Actual flood flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, the density of actual flows represents floodwater that impacts people or property, after accounting for flood routing due to topography, stream networks, and natural and artificial features that detain, slow, or infiltrate floodwater.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Flood source
page.title: Flood damaging runoff
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows runoff that actually harms people or damages property when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual mitigation
page.title: Utilized runoff mitigation
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns. For provisioning services, such sinks are responsible for reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows sinks that actively reduce floodwater, providing the benefit of reduced flood damage for people.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual damage
page.title: Flood damage received
page.description:
The *actual use map* shows the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users located across the landscape.
This map shows actual damage received by people and property when accounting for sources of floodwater and their sinks and flow paths.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Absorbed floodwater
page.title: Absorbed flood flow
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* shows the flow paths that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss in possible flow of beneficial services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows flood flows that are absorbed by sinks prior to reaching human beneficiaries of flood regulation.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Mitigated floodwater
page.title: Mitigated flood source
page.description:
The *blocked source map* shows the part of the source map that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of the users and the flow dynamics, but was blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it reaches the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows the portion of the total runoff that is absorbed, detained, or slowed by the action of flood sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Total benefit
page.title: Flood mitigation benefits accrued
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the service carrier based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued to users because of sinks; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and natural sink features.
This map shows people or economically valuable assets who are spared from flood damage due to the flood regulation activity of sinks.
page.see-also: The flood regulation section of the ARIES web site
